title: Dramatic Techniques Quiz
description: Explore the craft of drama, from soliloquies to stage directions and theatrical devices

questions.question: What is a 'soliloquy' in drama?
options: A speech in which a character speaks their thoughts aloud while alone on stage
A song performed by the chorus

questions.question: What is a 'monologue'?
options: The final scene of a play
A long speech by one character, which may be addressed to others on stage

questions.question: What is an 'aside' in theater?
options: A mistake made by an actor
A remark made by a character to the audience that other characters on stage do not hear

questions.question: What is the 'chorus' in ancient Greek drama?
options: A group of performers who comment on the action, provide background, and express themes

questions.question: What does 'catharsis' mean in the context of drama?
options: The emotional release or purification experienced by the audience through pity and fear
The opening act of a play

questions.question: Who described catharsis as a key purpose of tragedy?
What is a 'tragic flaw' (hamartia)?
options: A weakness or error in judgment that leads to the hero's downfall
A flaw in the stage design

questions.question: What is 'comic relief'?
options: A humorous scene or character inserted into a serious work to provide a break from tension
The main humor in a comedy
The final joke of a comedy

questions.question: What are the 'three unities' in classical drama, as described by Aristotle?
What is 'dramatic irony' in a play?
options: When two characters share a secret
When the audience knows something the characters do not
When a character tells a joke

questions.question: What is a 'prologue' in drama?
options: An introductory section that establishes the context of the play
The final speech of a play

questions.question: What is an 'epilogue' in drama?
options: A closing section that provides commentary or resolution after the main action

questions.question: What is 'hubris' in the context of tragic drama?
options: Excessive pride or arrogance that leads to a character's downfall

questions.question: In Shakespearean drama, what is a 'foil' character?
options: A character whose qualities contrast with and highlight those of another character
A character who appears only briefly
A character who uses a sword

questions.question: What does 'suspension of disbelief' mean for a theater audience?
options: Refusing to believe anything in the play
The audience's willingness to accept the fictional world of the play as temporarily real
A technique used only in magic shows
